image.altText: A woman wearing a blue shirt looks back over her shoulder towards the camera.

props.synopsis: Tasmania could become the first state to introduce minimum sentences for child sex offenders as Labor flips its position, but the controversial legislation has drawn the ire of legal groups and victim-survivor Grace Tame.

title.children: 'Great in theory': Grace Tame's warning as Tasmanian Labor flips to support mandatory child abuse sentencing

image.altText: A man in a white shirt and tie shows someone around an art gallery.

props.synopsis: In a series of letters read to a court, a prominent Tasmanian art dealer details how a convicted paedophile was continuing to negotiate the sale of his colonial art collection while in jail to divest his assets.

title.children: Court hears details of jailed paedophile's attempts to offload art to hide assets from victim

image.altText: A satellite photo showing the Al-Shifa hospital complex in Gaza, surrounded by suburban rooftops

props.synopsis: The Israeli military launches a "precise and targeted operation" inside Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital. Follow live.

title.children: Israeli military forces raid Gaza's largest hospital in operation against Hamas

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A member of Hamas' political office says Israel's attempt to portray its "incursion" inside Al-Shifa hospital as a success is "politically juvenile" and "an exposed theatrical move which won't work on anyone". In a video seen by the ABC, Ezzat Al-Racheq says Al-Shifa is sheltering ill and injured people, alongside displaced Gazans, doctors and nurses. "The arrival of the occupations tanks to the Shifa is not an achievement, for the Shifa is a civilian medical refuge and not a military barracks," he said. "And Netanyahu and his army's attempts to depict that as an achievement or victory, demonstrates failure, confusion and the depth of their defeat that they are incurring." Al-Racheq also said the US's readiness to go along with claims Hamas uses the hospitals, made President Joe Biden a "full partner with the occupation in this crime".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's military operation in Al-Shifa 'not an achievement', Hamas says

children.content: A member of Hamas' political office says Israel's attempt to portray its "incursion" inside Al-Shifa hospital as a success is "politically juvenile" and "an
exposed theatrical move which won't work on anyone".
In a video seen by the ABC, Ezzat Al-Racheq says Al-Shifa is sheltering ill and injured people, alongside displaced Gazans, doctors and nurses.
"The arrival of the occupations tanks to the Shifa is not an achievement, for the Shifa is a civilian medical refuge and not a military barracks," he said.
"And Netanyahu and his army's attempts to depict that as an achievement or victory, demonstrates failure, confusion and the depth of their defeat that they are incurring."
Al-Racheq also said the US's readiness to go along with claims Hamas uses the hospitals, made President Joe Biden a "full partner with the occupation in this crime".

props.alt: Man sits in front of zoom background of Palestinian territory

children.content: Hamas political office and media member Ezzat Al-Racheq is seen in this video denouncing the operation inside Al-Shifa.
(Supplied)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel has repeatedly said Hamas is using underground tunnels in Al-Shifa to hide, which they say has led to this military operation. But this is not the first time Israel has said that. They previously said Hamas used underground areas in Al-Shifa during a 2008-2009 war, according to Reuters. That war saw more than 1,400 Palestinians and 13 Israelis killed. It was not possible to verify the claims at the time, Reuters says. The New York Times says one of their journalists in 2008 watched armed Hamas militants walking around Al-Shifa Hospital in civilian clothes. Amnesty Internationa l concluded in the 2014 conflict that Hamas used parts of Al-Shifa "to detain, interrogate, torture and otherwise ill-treat suspects, even as other parts of the hospital continued to function as a medical center".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: This is not the first time Israel has said there are Hamas tunnels under Al-Shifa Hospital

children.content: Israel has repeatedly said
Hamas is using underground tunnels in Al-Shifa
to hide, which they say has led to this military operation.
But this is not the first time Israel has said that.
They previously said Hamas used underground areas in Al-Shifa during a 2008-2009 war,
according to Reuters.
That war saw more than 1,400 Palestinians and 13 Israelis killed.
It was not possible to verify the claims at the time, Reuters says.
The New York Times says one of their journalists in 2008
watched armed Hamas militants
walking around Al-Shifa Hospital in civilian clothes.
Amnesty Internationa
l concluded in the 2014
conflict that Hamas used parts of Al-Shifa "to detain, interrogate, torture and otherwise ill-treat suspects, even as other parts of the hospital continued to function as a medical center".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Mikaela Ortolan and Mike Lorigan Offices of government MPs have been targeted by activists protesting the number of Palestinian civilians being killed in Gaza. The entrances of several Victorian Labor MPs in Melbourne were blocked with fake bodies in body bags this morning. The protest material was removed within hours. Fifteen body bags were laid outside each office, which the group says equates to the number of Palestinian deaths per hour in Gaza. Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said he was aware that his Geelong office had been targeted. "My first concern is always for the safety and wellbeing of my staff," he said in a statement. The offices of Bill Shorten, Ged Kearney and Peter Khalil were also among those targeted. The group is calling on the Labor government to immediately cut all diplomatic and economic support of Israel, end arms supplies and is demanding an immediate ceasefire. One of the organisers, who asked to be only named as Linda, said the small group of about 10 protesters were parents and healthcare workers motivated by their horror at civilian deaths in Gaza. She said she apologised to anyone who was saddened or disturbed by this morning's action. "I can really appreciate that people found it jarring and disturbing," she said. "I found it disturbing preparing for the action, but is there anything more harrowing than a dead child? This is the reality, in real life, for the people in Gaza." She said the group felt this was the only way to get through to politicians after failed petitions and letters that had no response. Mr Shorten's office declined to comment. The ABC is contacting other MPs whose offices were targeted. Victoria Police has confirmed it is investigating the incidents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pro-Palestinian activists target offices of government MPs with fake bodies

children.content: Reporting by Mikaela Ortolan and Mike Lorigan
Offices of government MPs have been targeted by activists protesting the number of Palestinian civilians being killed in Gaza.
The entrances of several Victorian Labor MPs in Melbourne were blocked with fake bodies in body bags this morning. The protest material was removed within hours.
Fifteen body bags were laid outside each office, which the group says equates to the number of Palestinian deaths per hour in Gaza.
Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said he was aware that his Geelong office had been targeted.
"My first concern is always for the safety and wellbeing of my staff," he said in a statement.

props.alt: White cloth with red stains wrapped in the shape of a body laid out with signs in front of a building with a window

children.content: The protesters published photos on Instagram of their action, which targeted the office of Defence Minister Richard Marles.
(ABC News)
The offices of Bill Shorten, Ged Kearney and Peter Khalil were also among those targeted.
The group is calling on the Labor government to immediately cut all diplomatic and economic support of Israel, end arms supplies and is demanding an immediate ceasefire.
One of the organisers, who asked to be only named as Linda, said the small group of about 10 protesters were parents and healthcare workers motivated by their horror at civilian deaths in Gaza.
She said she apologised to anyone who was saddened or disturbed by this morning's action.
"I can really appreciate that people found it jarring and disturbing," she said.
"I found it disturbing preparing for the action, but is there anything more harrowing than a dead child? This is the reality, in real life, for the people in Gaza."
She said the group felt this was the only way to get through to politicians after failed petitions and letters that had no response.

props.alt: White cloths with red stains wrapped in the shape of a body and laid in front of a closed shop front with red sign reading andrew giles

children.content: Scullin MP Andrew Giles, whose electorate office is in Melbourne's north, was also among those targeted by protesters.
(ABC News)
Mr Shorten's office declined to comment. The ABC is contacting other MPs whose offices were targeted.
Victoria Police has confirmed it is investigating the incidents.

image.altText: A red and yellow brig building with a silver sign reading Tandara Lodge.

props.synopsis: Wayne Rouse collapsed in his aged care facility after trying to call for assistance. When staff did reach him, they did not help as it was thought he had a "do not resuscitate" order in place — but that was wrong, a coroner finds.

title.children: CPR not given to an aged care resident because of a misunderstanding, coroner finds

image.altText: Two power transmission towers in the middle on an open field with a sunrise in the background.,

props.synopsis: A scorching hot summer could see demand for electricity spike to a once-in-a-decade high, we're being warned, increasing the risk of blackouts, and forced power outages across the country.

title.children: Bushfires and heatwaves set to drive 'extreme' demand for power, increasing risk of blackouts

image.altText: Tyler Whitton's family wear shirts with his name on the front

props.synopsis: Tyler Whitton was still legally a child when he went to work at a Brisbane construction site for the final time.

title.children: 'Bring his blood from the concrete': Family of 17-year-old apprentice killed in workplace accident speak out

image.altText: Firefighting crews battle a large foiefront in bushland near Lightning Ridge.

props.synopsis: People in the Glengarry area of north west NSW have been told it is too late to leave and Grawin residents have been told to evacuate towards Lightning Ridge as firefighters and water-bombers work to contain the bushfire.

title.children: Glengarry residents told 'too late to leave' as NSW fires impacts homes, property

image.altText: A man sits outside Parliament House with a dog and a sign that says 'Day 14 Climate Hunger Strike'.

props.synopsis: Two years ago, Gregory Andrews was the high commissioner to West Africa, where he was responsible for promoting Australia's mining interests. Today, he is on the lawns of Parliament House, 14 days into a hunger strike protesting the lack of government action on climate change.

title.children: Gregory Andrews used to be a senior Liberal adviser. Now he's 14 days into a climate action hunger strike

image.altText: Troye Sivan at the ARIA Awards

props.synopsis: Australia's biggest music industry names are gathering to celebrate the 2023 ARIA Awards in Sydney. Follow live.

title.children: Troye Sivan takes home two awards as Kylie, Genesis Owusu claim ARIA gongs

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ARIA for Best Original Soundtrack or Musical Theatre Cast Album goes to John Farnham: Finding The Voice (Music from the Feature Documentary) — Various Artists. Here's what Dan Condon had to say: John Farnham and Glenn Wheatley cannot stop their domination of the Australian music scene. Wheatley died early in 2022, and Farnham has been out of the spotlight fighting cancer for over a year. Yet they still won tonight, taking out Best Original Soundtrack for the soundtrack to this year's documentary John Farnham: Finding The Voice.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: WINNER: John Farnham: Finding The Voice  — Best Original Soundtrack or Musical Theatre Cast Album

children.content: The ARIA for Best Original Soundtrack or Musical Theatre Cast Album goes to John Farnham: Finding The Voice (Music from the Feature Documentary) — Various Artists.
Here's what Dan Condon had to say:

John Farnham and Glenn Wheatley cannot stop their domination of the Australian music scene. Wheatley died early in 2022, and Farnham has been out of the spotlight fighting cancer for over a year. Yet they still won tonight, taking out Best Original Soundtrack for the soundtrack to this year's documentary John Farnham: Finding The Voice.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's the second win for Troye and Stylaz who earlier claimed Best Produced. Presented by Meg Mac, who is also up for a gong tonight, the pair once again are on stage, bringing Alex Ghenea with them to accept the award. Troye is the first artist to claim two awards tonight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: WINNER: Best Engineered Release — Styalz Fuego for Troye Sivan — Rush

children.content: It's the second win for Troye and Stylaz who earlier claimed Best Produced.
Presented by Meg Mac, who is also up for a gong tonight, the pair once again are on stage, bringing
Alex Ghenea with them to accept the award.
Troye is the first artist to claim two awards tonight.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The incredible Joy McKean is honoured by Australian country star Troy Cassar-Daley. She was the brains behind Slim Dusty's extraordinary career, writing many of his biggest songs. Read more about her incredible life here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Remembering Joy McKean

featuredLink.title: Joy McKean was Australian music's fiercest trailblazer - Double J

children.content: The incredible
Joy McKean
is honoured by Australian country star Troy Cassar-Daley.
She was the brains behind Slim Dusty's extraordinary career, writing many of his biggest songs.

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a blue air force uniform looks grim in front of the side doors to Parliament House.

props.synopsis: The senior Air Force officer recently appointed as the National Cyber Security Coordinator has been recalled to Defence to deal with what the department describes as a "workplace matter".

title.children: Defence recalls cybersecurity coordinator Air Marshal Darren Goldie

image.altText: Soccer player Nestory Irankunda with father Gideon at Hindmarsh Stadium.

props.synopsis: Nestory Irankunda is still a teenager but has the soccer world at his feet, his skills set to be let loose on the international stage after his signing with German giant Bayern Munich.

title.children: Nestory Irankunda's signing with Bayern Munich is a 'watershed moment' for Australian soccer

image.altText: A sign that reads "Old Timers Village".

props.synopsis: Twenty-four residents and four staff at the Old Timers Village in Alice Springs have returned positive tests.

title.children: NT aged care facility in lockdown as one third of residents test positive for COVID-19

image.altText: A row of NSW police shoulder patches are seen as officers stand in a line.

props.synopsis: A senior NSW detective is charged with drink driving following an investigation into a crash earlier this year.

title.children: NSW Police reject 'cover-up' after detective charged with drink driving months after crash

image.altText: A waitress in a white shirt carries a tray of glasses in a Canberra restaurant.

props.synopsis: Wages post their biggest quarterly increase in at least a quarter of a century, due to big pay boosts for aged care staff and workers on awards.

title.children: Despite the biggest wages rise on record, the real pay of Australian workers is stuck near a 13-year low

image.altText: Immigration generic by Emma Machan

props.synopsis: Some of the detainees released from immigration detention were sent into the community without visas, a revelation that appears to contradict what the federal government has said in recent days.

title.children: Detainees released without visas after High Court decision in immigration revelation

image.altText: A lady on a red carpet, a man on a red carpet, and another lady on a red carpet

props.synopsis: Celebrities have walked the red carpet before the 2023 ARIA Awards kick off at Sydney's Hordern Pavilion. Here's a look at some of the outfits we've seen.

title.children: ARIA awards red carpet: Bright colours, sleek suits, and a nod to Rihanna's Met Gala outfit

image.altText: A group of women and children on the back of a van

props.synopsis: As a humanitarian disaster unfolds in Gaza, the United States fears a power vacuum will soon follow. But Palestinian leaders say the current ideas for post-war Gaza aren't viable.

title.children: America has an idea for what post-war Gaza could look like. Here's why almost everyone is against it

image.altText: optus 'yes' sign on glass fronted office block

props.synopsis: More Australians are reporting being targeted by cybercriminals, as the nation's digital spy agency points the finger at China as the major backer of serious hacking of Australian companies and critical infrastructure.

title.children: China blamed as major backer behind hacking of Australian companies and infrastructure

image.altText: police use battering ram to hit gate

props.synopsis: An underworld network alleged to have dealt with $1 billion in drugs, guns and money laundering is brought down after a widescale NSW Police and Australian Border Force operation.

title.children: 'Potentially biggest criminal network in Australia' dismantled by police after raids across Sydney

image.altText: Jarnail Singh holding pieces of paper.

props.synopsis: Jarnail has always felt at home in Tasmania. But for the last few months, he's been the target of ongoing racial abuse — but rather than cop it in silence, he is speaking out in the hope it helps others.

title.children: Indian restaurant owner takes stand against racist abuse after vile letters, damage to car, graffiti

image.altText: The Riverlea housing project at Buckland Park in Adelaide's north.

props.synopsis: On the one hand, is a $3 billion development to accommodate thousands of families. On the other, is a burial site that is of immeasurable cultural significance. The problem? They are both on the same ground.

title.children: It looks like an oasis, but the Riverlea development has been harbouring a secret

image.altText: Kylie Minogue wearing a red dress and long red gloves, looking away from the camera with hand on hip and longish blonde hair

props.synopsis: Australian music's night of nights is here, the 2023 ARIA Awards. This is the full list of nominees which will be updated live with all the winners once the ceremony begins.

title.children: ARIA Awards 2023: Emma Memma wins Best Children's Album — see the full list of winners as they come through

image.altText: A wooden pillar is deteriorating below a bridge

props.synopsis: Harvey community members are concerned that the sudden closure of Forestry Road bridge for urgent repairs could cut the town off from supply trucks and emergency vehicles.

title.children: 'Catastrophic' risk closes bridge, with locals and vital services facing lengthy detours

image.altText: aerial view of a car crossing a bridge in an outback setting

props.synopsis: The Queensland Audit Office reports that the state's councils over the past five years have found assets such as vast stretches of road, lost due to administrative blunders.

title.children: Council finds $32m worth of footpaths, pipes and other assets it didn't realise it owned

image.altText: A woman with her head in her hands.

props.synopsis: Relatives of two teenagers who were taken to hospital after self-harming at the notorious Unit 18 over the weekend slam the government's claim the facility is safe. WARNING: This story discusses incidents of self-harm and contains the image of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: Boy who self-harmed in youth custody claims he was treated ‘like an animal’ as family speaks out

image.altText: Elizabeth Debicki in character as Princess Diana wearing a blue swimsuit

props.synopsis: Costumer designers say they don't make every outfit an exact replica for characters on the royal drama, but certain outfits this season were non-negotiable.

title.children: How similar are Princess Diana's costumes on The Crown to the real-life photos?

image.altText: Makeshift tents cover the area in front of a multi-storey stone hospital building, two ambulances are in the foreground

props.synopsis: The Israeli army says it is carrying out a "targeted" operation in the enclave's largest hospital, while people trapped in the hospital say they are preparing to bury patients who have died under Israeli encirclement.

title.children: Israel raids Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital, as people trapped in the hospital dig mass graves

image.altText: A man with a shaved head, wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton says parliament should keep sitting until legislation is passed to address the High Court decision that has led to the release of 83 people from immigration detention, among them criminals.

title.children: Dutton calls for ongoing parliament until High Court immigration decision addressed

image.altText: A picture of a stone grave with a plaque missing.

props.synopsis: Police allege the plaques were taken from gravestones at Sunshine Coast cemeteries in early November and sold to second-hand metal dealers with the names removed.

title.children: Two men accused of stealing brass plaques from graves and selling metal

image.altText: A drone photo of a Tiger shark.

props.synopsis: More Surf Life Saving volunteers will be trained up to operate shark-spotting drones over patrol popular beaches this summer, to help protect swimmers after recent attacks.

title.children: Drone surveillance to be ramped up after two shark attacks in regional SA

image.altText: A woman with silver hair in a purple shirt standing in a garden in front of metal scraps used for sculptures.

props.synopsis: Jo Caminiti spent years in pain and being so tired she could barely walk as doctors failed to link her symptoms to perimenopause. She says a simple treatment "transformed" her life overnight.

title.children: When Jo felt her life was 'falling apart', doctors had no answers. Then she saw a news show and diagnosed herself

image.altText: An Optus store sign seen through a border of leaves.

props.synopsis: Optus is no stranger to class actions after last year's cyber attack. But a week after its crippling nationwide outage left 10 million Australians in the dark and businesses unable to trade, is another one on the horizon?

title.children: So you want to sue Optus for its outage. Here's why it might not be your best option

image.altText: A large number of naked people standing in waist deep water, photographed from behind, looking at hills beyond

props.synopsis: Spencer Tunick has photographed thousands of naked people all over the world, from Barcelona to Bondi. In November, it's Brisbane's turn.

title.children: Wear no underwear and listen to the megaphone: What to do at the Spencer Tunick shoot in Brisbane
